column1: The risk of cancer increases to about 10% in women with postmenopausal bleeding.
Make sure that bleeding is coming from the vagina and is not from the rectum or the urine.
Because aspirin may prolong bleeding, it should be avoided, if possible.
However, NSAIDS such as ibuprofen can be used to minimize bleeding and cramping.

Call your health care provider if: - You are pregnant - There is any unexplained bleeding between periods - There is any bleeding after menopause - There is heavy bleeding with periods - Abnormal bleeding is accompanied by other symptoms, such as pain, fatigue, dizziness
- Do you have any other symptoms such as abdominal pain, bruising, pain when urinating, or blood in urine or stools?
